roll out.translation[0].definitions[0].d: to make food that you are preparing flat and thin by pushing a rolling pin over it
roll out.translation[0].definitions[0].e: Roll out the dough on a floured surface.
roll out.translation[0].definitions[1].d: to make a new product available for people to buy or use
roll out.translation[0].definitions[1].e: The company expects to roll out the new software in September.
roll out.translation[0].definitions[2].d: to leave a place, especially later than expected
roll out.translation[0].definitions[2].e: We used to hear people rolling out of the pubs at closing time.
He finally rolled out of bed at noon.
roll out.translation[0].definitions[3].d: to put something flat on the ground or a surface, when it was previously rolled into a tube shape
roll out.translation[0].definitions[3].e: We rolled out our sleeping bags under the stars.
roll out.translation[0].definitions[4].d: to make special preparations for an important visitor
roll out.translation[1].definitions[0].d: an occasion when a new product is made available for people to buy or use
roll out.translation[1].definitions[0].e: Sun had to cancel the intended roll-out of the 514 model.
roll out.translation[2].definitions[0].d: to supply a new product to shops and companies in a region or country after it has been successfully tested and marketed in a small area
roll out.translation[2].definitions[0].e: The company expects to roll several new products soon.
